details.title: A study on a single-unit Markov repairable system with repair time omission
details.standardTitle: A study on a single-unit Markov repairable system with repair time omission

p: Zhihua Zheng received the B.S. degree in mathematics from Inner Mongolia Normal University, China, in 2000, and is working toward the M.S. degree in operational research & cyberneticsin at the School of Management & Economics, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, China.
Her research interests are reliability engineering, stochastic modeling, applications of probability, and statistics.
Lirong Cui received the Ph.D. degree in statistics from the University of Wales, U.K., in 1994.

He is a Professor in the School of Management & Economics, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, China. He has been working on reliability-related problems since 1986. His research interests are stochastic modeling, quality and reliability engineering, simulation and optimization, risk management, software development for quality and reliability, operations research, and applications of probability and statistics in various fields.
Dr. Cui currently serves as an Associate Editor in the IEEE Transactions on Reliability.
Alan G. Hawkes received the B.S. degree in mathematics from London University, U.K., in 1960, and the Ph.D. degree in statistics in 1966.

He lectured at the University College London and Durham University before becoming a Full Professor at Swansea University in 1974. He is currently a Research Professor in the European Business Management School, University of Wales, U.K., where he was the Chair before retiring. His research interests are applied stochastic modeling with publications in queuing theory, point process theory, reliability of repairable systems, and most significantly, stochastic modeling of biological ion channels, a vital part of our physiological control system.

details.abstract: This paper introduces a new model for a single-unit Markov repairable system in which repair times that are sufficiently short (less than some critical value) do not result in system failure. We can say that such a repair interval is omitted from the downtime record. First we suppose that the critical repair time is a constant. The model is then generalized to allow the critical repair time to be a non-negative random variable. We calculate system availability for these new models as a measure of reliability. Some numerical examples are given to illustrate the results in the paper.

citations.title: A study on a single-unit Markov repairable system with repair time omission

context.text: A great deal of research has been devoted to Markov repairable systems with a single-unit [1], and the Markov repairable system has been widely used in reliability theory and practice [5], [6].

It is well-known that the instantaneous, and steady-state system availabilities for a single-unit Markov repairable system (the original system, because of Markov property) are, for example, in [1], .

links.abstract: The transient behavior of a system with operational and repair times distributed following phase-type distributions is studied. These times are alternated in the evolution of the system, and they form 2 separate geometric processes. The stationary study of this system when the repair times form a renewal process has been made . This paper also considers that operational times are partitioned into two well-distinguished classes successively occupied: good, and preventive. An algorithmic approach ...

context.text: Further work on this topic is still current, for example that by Rafael Perez-Ocon & Montoro-Cazorla [7] who, using phase-type distributions and geometric processes, analyzed a repairable system.

references.title:
Transient analysis of a repairable system, using phase-type
distributions and geometric processes
references.text: R. Perez-Ocon, D. Montoro-Cazorla, "Transient analysis of a repairable system using phase-type distributions and geometric processes", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 53, no. 2, pp. 185-192, June 2004.

links.abstract: Preventive maintenance planning, and production scheduling are two activities that are inter-dependent but most often performed independently. Considering that preventive maintenance, and repair affect both available production time, and the probability of machine failure, we are surprised that this inter-dependency seems to be overlooked in the literature. We propose an integrated model that coordinates preventive maintenance planning decisions with single-machine scheduling decisions so that t...

context.text: Cassady & Kutanoglu [8] proposed an integrated model that coordinates preventive maintenance planning decisions with single-machine scheduling decisions so that the total expected weighted completion time of jobs is minimized.

references.title:
Integrating preventive maintenance planning and production
scheduling for a single machine
references.text: C. R. Cassady, E. Kutanoglu, "Integrating preventive maintenance planning and production scheduling for a single machine", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 54, no. 2, pp. 304-309, June 2005.
